data.expected: BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
data.sampled: Please make sure your input is correct. The dominant allele for this question is represented by the letter 'B', for blue. The possible genotypes for this problem are BB, B_ (with _ standing for either G or T), and GG. The possible phenotypes are BB, BB+ (with + standing for either B or G), B_B, BB+G, BGB, B_B_ (with _ standing for either G or T), and BB+T.

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green

options: BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG

data.expected: GT (Green) x GT (Green) -> 1/4 GG (Green), 1/2 GT (Green), 1/4 TT (Turquoise)

Bungalow x Bunting -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BBG, 1/4 G_
But if Turquoise is invisible, then the possible phenotypes of the F1 generation are:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Turquoise
So, the possible genotypes of the parents are BB and GG, and the possible genotypes of the offspring are BB, BBG, GG, and G_, where _ refers to the invisible allele.
